instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.CHGR_PHASE: What is CHGR_PHASE? CHGR_PHASE is charger voltage chopped up into individual slices prior to smoothing where it becomes PPBUS_G3H.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
We got this board in with a green light turning orange but no fan spin. The board was liquid damaged around <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>, the bottom left corner of the board near <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>, the SMC RESET IC, and BADLY by the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>. Reflowed areas of corrosion and replaced almost any component left of the ISL as well as the ISL itself. I checked each individual pin for continuity throughout the circuit and all was good. Resistance between 17/18 and 27/28 is good both 20 ohm and 3 ohn measurements. The first time I did replace it, the ISL got SUPER hot, and I did not get a green light. I went ahead and replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> and the ISL again and now I'm back to square one on the problem with a green light that turns orange with no fan spin and only 1 volt on PPBUS. Measurements below at the ISL:

DCIN: 18 volts
ACIN: 4.48 volts
BCACOK: 3.3
<SIGNAL>RESET_L</SIGNAL>: 3.3
17/18: 3.9 ohms
27/28: 20.9 ohms.

Any and all help is appreciated 

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Charger U GATE is 5.5 volts and L gate is 50 millivolts. The SMBUS lines are both 3.3. I'm just making sure because I've replaced a lot of stuff so far, is this another bad ISL chip? <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> appears to be opening now as I get 18 volts on the source and 7 in the gate. And the ISL is not scolding hot anymore

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 1V is usually a short on PPBUS, resistance to GND?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Resistance is 0.68 kilohms. My thinking is maybe <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> are bad and killing my ISL?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: There definitely was some corrosion near <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> and like I said the ISL and all components on the left of it were replaced because lots of corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 680 Ohm to GND on PPBUS is way too low. All the FETs and <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> should always be replaced together as one kills the other. Also verify all traces to the FETs gate pin.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I'm confused now. I have replaced all of the components but something weird happens when I put <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> on the board. With just a new <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>, ISL, and <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> my resistance to ground on PPBUS is many kilohms. HOWEVER, when I put <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> on the board, the resistance to ground drops to around 0.62 kilohms. I have checked continuity from 6 and 7 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> to the other side of the board and I get continuity.

In diode mode with <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> on the board:

Pin 2: 0.557 on or off the board
Pin 7: 0.128 seems really low compared to donor, normal measurement consistent with donor when off of the board
Pin 6: 0.499 on or off board

I checked my soldering, I have tried a few <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>'s from an identical donor and a few Air boards (don't have anymore Retina boards I can try), and each time I put it on the board, the resistance measurements on PPBUS and <SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL> go down. I have also replaced <CAPACITOR>C7145</CAPACITOR> as it looked nasty. No short on that line or any of the lines that I can find unless I put <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> on the board. Is there anything else that can be causing this to go low? Don't want to put power through until I relieve that short or I want to know if it normally pulls the resistance down when on the board (doesn't seem like it).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Resistance to ground on CPU Vcore is 50 ohms btw with no <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Is resistance to GND on PPBUS the same with polarity swapped on multimeter probes?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I did not check that. I will check it when I get back to it tomorrow for sure. Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: It will tell you if it is a semiconductor resistance or a pure resistive one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Ok so black probe to ground red probe to the PPBUS fuse: 310 kilohms to ground.
Red probe to ground black probe to the fuse I'm getting about 20 kilohms. I would guess that means I have some kind of short?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
With a <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> on the board: 

Black probe to ground red probe to fuse: 20 kilohms
Red probe to ground black probe to fuse: 0.5kilohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Different polarity causing resistance difference so this is not something to worry about. Remove the fuse and see if PPBUS comes up, eliminate the system pulling it down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Pin 1 of F7140 resistance is low 0.4 kilohms. Resistance on Pin 2 is millions of ohms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: When I put power through pin 1, I don't get a short the amperage is 0...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Any ideas? I can't figure out what is up I get a low resistance measurement on the creation side, but if I put any voltage through either side, I get zero on the creation side and 0.010 amps on the system side. Could this be a blown internal trace? Nothing seems to get hot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
At 400 Ohm nothing will get hot as this is way to much resistance to let any significant current flow. I have no idea what is going on right now.

For testing, the board should be able to power on from a charged battery with the fuse removed. Need to short the power on pads of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok I will check to see if it will.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1 volt on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Me too :( it's weird because all my traces have continuity to where they need to go, but no matter what I do, <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> creates a small short. And I've tried at least 10 <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>'s. Oh well if it is a short in the board, it is what it is
